intro: Lupinus soukupianus, commonly known as the southern lupine, is a perennial flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its tall, erect stems and clusters of pea-like flowers that range in color from white to purple. The plant has compound leaves with small, oval-shaped leaflets and produces pods that contain several seeds. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in rocky or arid environments, showcasing its adaptability to harsh conditions.
